item.title: Add geom_hline to ggplot2 legend
item.description: library(pander) library(tidyverse) library(lubridate) a = data.frame(x_val = seq(from = ymd_hms("2050-01-01 00:00:00"), to = ymd_hms("2050-12-31 23:59:59"), by = "1 day"), y_val = 1:365) plt = ggplot(data = a) + geom_line(aes(x = x_val, y = y_val, colour = "Variable"), # if there are multiple variables then change that to column heading size = 0.1) + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 32, linetype = "Legend")) + scale_x_datetime(name = "", date_labels = "%b", date_breaks = "1 month") + theme(legend.

item.title: Keep only complete rows with no NA values
item.description: Keep only complete rows (omit any row with NA values) dt <- dt[complete.cases(dt)] dt <- dt %>% .[complete.cases(.)]

item.title: Remove rows with all NA
item.description: Remove rows with all NA but keep any row with at least 1 observation: dt <- dt[rowSums(is.na(x)) <= 1] dt <- dt %>% .[rowSums(is.na(.)) <= 1]

item.title: Split a data.table into a list by row number
item.description: Split a data.table into a list by row. Each row element then becomes an element in the list. dt <- dt[, row_id := .I] listy <- split(dt, dt$row_id) or this may be simpler as it eliminates the requirement to create an additional column holding the row numbers. listy <- split(dt, seq(nrow(dt)))

item.title: Test if all values in column are NA
item.description: Test if all values in a column are NA. all(is.na(dt$column)) # TRUE all(is.na(c(NA, 0, NA))) # FALSE Links: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9417391/how-to-check-if-entire-vector-has-no-values-other-than-na-or-nan-in-r

item.title: How to deploy your GitHub website with GitHub Pages
item.description: Simply follow the instructions on GitHub Pages link which is equivalent to: Create a new empty repository following this EXACT naming convention: username.github.io Where username == your user name on github Ex. if my user name is Scott then the repository should be named Scott.github.io Do not initialize a README file If you are using blogdown then create a git repository in the public folder Commit everything in the public folder and push to your newly created repository DONE!

item.title: About Hugo XMin
item.description: XMin is the first Hugo theme I have designed. The original reason that I wrote it was I needed a minimal example of Hugo themes when I was writing the blogdown book. Basically I wanted a simple theme that supports a navigation menu, a home page, other single pages, lists of pages, blog posts, categories, tags, and RSS. That is all. Nothing fancy. In terms of CSS and JavaScript, I really want to keep them minimal.
